item.title: Students Protesting again

item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Lothy:

we’re approaching a point in time in which, due to technology, not everyone needs to work all of the time as they do now.

The working class work all of the time now. We are definitely far beyond the point where everyone is working even close to all of the time.

Read full topic

item.title: Students Protesting again
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I agree with Greeny. Nobody talks about it, but everyone knows it’s the truth – Universities in Australia, among other countries, are factories for pumping out degrees.
There’s only so many jobs available, especially in fields like chemical engineering, physics, etc. Jobs in these fields don’t grow on trees. The advent of the computer hasn’t really helped job prospects like it has productivity, at least outside of the IT industry.

And the medical profession is getting worse. People go into medicine here thinking that they’ll be snapped up for jobs before they can shake the hand of the person giving them their degree at the graduation ceremony.
The truth is that Australia does indeed need doctors, but these people are forgetting that they’re not doctors yet – they’re merely interns.
There’s a bit of a scare at the moment, because the health industry is worried that there won’t be enough places for this generation of medical students to actually do their intern.

To be honest, I don’t see capitalism working beyond the next 30 to 50 years. At least not in its current form where everyone is expected to work.
As a race, we’re approaching a point in time in which, due to technology, not everyone needs to work all of the time as they do now.
In fact, it’s getting that way now. Factory jobs that still employ people when machines could (certainly would) do both a better and quicker job; cashiers are redundant too.

Read full topic

item.title: Students Protesting again
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Oh I do know how much they charge for international students, I know many.

See, I know what you’re saying about people coming out of University and thinking they’re automatically going to jump into a better job because of that. Most don’t understand it is the experience that employers value most, especially at a young age, it doesn’t matter what qualifications you have if you have no experience.

It should be seen as something that will eventually help you go down a better career path, or maybe progress faster in your career, but the first few jobs will always be there just for experience - much like anyone who hadn’t gone to university.

As for it being harder to get into, pretty much all universities are upping their entry requirements this year. But I don’t necessarily agree with the idea of making less places available, but getting rid of the stupid, useless courses that won’t directly serve the person in helping them get a better job need to be gone, as do the lower requirement courses.

Read full topic

item.title: Students Protesting again
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Thug-life:

The Student loans are at something like 1% interest. Which is basically just counting for inflation, so where does the profit come from?

Yeah but times it by the number of students in the UK. You can never say a small percentage isn’t much until you know what the it actually represents. Plus, do you have any idea how much they charge international students. It’s like triple.

It used to be like 3-4%, it’s only go down because the bank of England base rate went down. You can thank the recession for that.

They say you pay back around the same as what you borrowed, because the interest closely matches inflation despite the fact they’re allowed to go 1% above the BoE base rate. You always pay more, and even if its only 1% of 500,000 UK students. That’s a lot of money.

EDIT: It’s not profiteering in the true sense of the word, but considering this is education I still think it should just be much harder to get in, less places and free. Ideally it would be easy to get in, less shit courses, more lecturers, more places and free. As a civilisation we should be aiming at advancement and progression - instead people (the entire world) are only bothered about making money, accounting for money, or stealing money.

Read full topic
